column31: The instructor could go more into detail on the details (like figuring out how to compress code down onto a single line using the special python approaches)
column33: I like how what is discussed in class is also followable on canvas itself, and so it is easy to find examples that were gone over in class that I was not able to write down.
column35: I like that it is over python. Python is a super cool language.
column37: I think the course could use a little more focus. Sometimes it feels like we talk about a subject and then leave the subject, but then we come back to it and it is a little confusing. By this, I don't mean that we come back to a subject after we learn more that will help us do more, because doing this makes sense. Instead I feel like we go back and forth sometimes without a ton of reason. (one example being not doing all file work stuff in a single given time, because we started working on argparse but then we came back to files and it seemed really odd).

column31: Explain in more detail what certain parts of python accomplish and how they work. A large majority of the class is showing code that we have not learned yet. A lot of our learning is reading the book or course information on our own, which is fine, but going over these concepts after we have read them would be very beneficial.
column33: Mr. Chappell was very helpful to students when a question was asked. He would provide the question and answers for all students on canvas. And he was very understanding when there was a problem or delay when turning in assignments.
column35: Python code is much simpler than other languages in that there is a lot of built in types, functions, and loops.
column37: Explain concepts without code first, then apply the code to the concepts that were taught.

column31: More enthusiastic delivery of the course material would help when trying to follow along in class.
column33: An abundance of material available on Canvas.
column35: The assignments, although too easy for the most part in my opinion, were fun to do.
column37: Assignments with more challenges to them would be nice.

column31: Hope the teacher teaches the lectures slowly, and explains the lecture's content more clearly For example, give a few examples so that students can understand how that function or program operates and understand the program's logic.
column33: I hope the teacher do not give us very hard functions, or program assignment. If give us a very hard program assignment, please give us some clues or idea to direct us. because python has many functions and syntax that we do not very familiar with.
column35: The best that I like about this course is that every time when I go to the teacher's office to ask the teacher some questions, the teacher is very patient to teach me, and helps me to solve the questions properly.
column37: I hope that teacher teaches the python's content more clearly and specifically. especially for some hard parts of python. Let students can really understand python, program logic, and type the code more efficiently than before.

column31: Slow down, Rather advanced topics are being thrown at us at a very fast rate and this is only a elective class.
column33: I like how if you are stuck on something he doesn't just leave you hanging.
column35: learning the basics of the language
column37: Don't try to get into as many advanced topics as possible, this is the first time that many have ever seen or heard of this language.

column31: This probably doesn’t apply to everyone but I do have a somewhat difficult time following along with the programming done in class. I try writing down as much of the programs as I can to reference back to but I never manage to get it all. It would be nice to get a copy/ text file of the programs written in class to reference back to. I know in some cases there are similar programs on canvas but this has not always been the case and it would be easier for me to look at what was specifically covered in class.
column33: How well the canvas is organized. I have never had a teacher put as much effort into making a good canvas experience for their students and I really enjoy that.
column37: Some kind of access to lecture notes that the teacher types up in class would be very beneficial to at least me personally.

column31: Speak slower. Try to keep student engage. Don't rush through the material.
column33: Help student when we ask for help

column31: Have greater clarity on the different method types and how they operate
column33: I liked how chill and passionate the instructor was with the course
column37:
Include more clarity on the functionality of different aspects of the python language

Change the due dates for projects so we can have the weekend to work on the projects instead of only Monday - Friday

column31:
Im not sure. Something about how he explains it makes it so that it doesn't stick with me.

dont put stuff on tests and quizes that havn't been on a submitted program. (IE: input/exceptions) Doing something first time on a test or quiz is incredibly stressful.
column35: Python. I really enjoy the language.
column37: more class time to work on the programs. college is busy and other classes have a ton of homework too.

column31: He seems a little bit nervous while teaching the class. Maybe be a little bit more confident
column33: He will work through programs similar to our homework assignments so we can learn alternative and more efficient means to work our programs
column35: I definitely feel a little bit more stretched in this course, which I feel is helping me understand python on a deeper level.
column37: I think having a quiz more often would be nice, so you don't have only 3 quiz grades by the end of the semester

column31: I think teaching through a python file as supposed to the terminal would be easier to understand.
column33: He covered multiple methods to solve the problems.
column37: Show more examples in the program format.

column31: I dont have ideas at this time
column33: He is willing to help a lot with problems to guide us.
column35: I think it has a mostly good pace of things so far
column37: Nothing that I can think of at the moment

column31: One thing would be to maybe ask for more class participation in lecture aspects to keep students motivated/interested.
column33: I like how he gave us many useful websites/resources to complete our programs and further our learning.
column35: That I feel like I'm actually learning something new.
column37: better detail in the explanation of some finer and complex terms.

column31: maybe quizzes can help?  he did good enough already
column33: He replies emails very detail and give me good examples
column35: learnt and played with pycharm to work with files
column37:
overall its pretty good and we learnt lot of useful commands in python.

one thing I would suggest is that we could have some written test or quiz, that might helps in students learning python as well.

also if we could have pycharm installed in lab computer would also help

column31: It would be nice if he could follow a more structured format for his presentations, it can be very hard to follow along sometimes.
column33: He is always willing to help with assignments.

column31:
Please, do NOT use idle for demonstrating code. It is very difficult to follow the changes and correct mistakes. Please use Pycharm or even notepad. 

Starting programs could be a bit more challenging. Now we are at a good level of difficulty for how far we are in the course.

It would have been helpful when using args to explain the parameters more. Telling us to go read the documentation isn't teaching.

Class time feels like too much talking and showing and not as much teaching
column33:
I like how he shows many different ways of solving a problem and allows us to choose one.

He shows us a good solution to the programs when we have completed them.
He is well educated in python
column35: The language is very fun. We get to explore many modules. He allows many ways to solve our programs. The programs are educational and easy.
column37:
Do not use IDLE past the first class period. That is not a real-world scenario.

Explain more of what = '__main__' does and its purpose vs just making the whole file main

During the first class, go over the style guides main requirements.

while learning obscure ways to do certain actions is fun, we should also focus on the most common ways.

program 6 example output should be more accurate. Allowing us to be within 5% of the correct answer doesn't teach us the correct way to achieve the correct outcome. Example: use regex to remove all punctuation instead of just a select few.

column31: I personally enjoy jumping around through various topics of python, but there's an uncertainty to me about what will be on quizzes and tests. I now realize that we are only tested over what we write programs for, at least that's how it seems, but many people in my class still aren't quite aware of that and I wasn't at the beginning. If we, for example, look at a database python module, is it just for our benefit that we're learning it, or is it going to be pertinent to passing the course? Detailing what is necessary to do well in the course and what is just for our benefit as programmers would be helpful. After all, this is an elective course. Most people who take this don't just care about a nice letter grade.
column33: Mr. Chappelle is very humble, and that makes him instantly likeable. As a northerner and someone with moderate ADHD, I find his talking speed a comfortable pace for the class and I feel like I'm learning a lot more in less time because of it. I also like his willingness to provide answers and communicate with his students.
column35: The maturity of it. The way the information and assignments are presented make me feel like the instructor/course respects my abilities. It's more open-ended and fun, but gives me room to think/search for things and learn on my own. I honestly love that and it's refreshing from other courses at this school.
column37: More clarity with quiz/test material is the primary thing. I know most of the people in the class, and some of them are having trouble not because they are bad programmers, but because of the scope of the material was broader than they expected. Written material and the instructor need to be more clear on what will be on tests and quizzes for study purposes.

column31: More detailed personal feedback on assignments would be nice, but that takes a lot of time, so not including it is understandable.
column33: He brings a great deal of enthusiasm for the language that is contagious.
column35: It has given me a base to be able to use this language in the future.
column37: Quicker feedback on assignments would be helpful, especially when a test is coming up.
